title: Practice Challenge
description: Create a basic GitHub Actions workflow for a .NET project.
instructions:
Create a CI workflow for ShopFlow!

1. Name the workflow 'ShopFlow CI'

2. Configure triggers:
   - Run on push to main branch
   - Run on pull requests to main branch

3. Create a single job 'build-and-test' that:
   - Runs on ubuntu-latest
   - Checks out the code
   - Sets up .NET 9.0
   - Restores dependencies
   - Builds in Release configuration
   - Runs tests

4. Follow the YAML structure for GitHub Actions workflows.

testCases.description: Should trigger on push to main

hints.text: Start with 'name: ShopFlow CI' at the top of the file.
The 'on' section uses push: and pull_request: with branches: [main] under each.
Steps use either 'uses:' for actions or 'run:' for shell commands.
Use actions/checkout@v4 and actions/setup-dotnet@v4 for the first two steps.
dotnet commands: restore, build --no-restore --configuration Release, test --no-build --configuration Release

commonMistakes.consequence: YAML parsing fails and the workflow does not run. GitHub shows a syntax error.
commonMistakes.correction: Use consistent 2-space indentation. Each nested level adds 2 spaces.

commonMistakes.consequence: GitHub Actions does not know whether the step is an action reference or a shell command.
commonMistakes.correction: Always prefix action references with 'uses:' and shell commands with 'run:'.

commonMistakes.consequence: Build fails because NuGet packages are not downloaded.
commonMistakes.correction: Always run 'dotnet restore' before 'dotnet build', or omit --no-restore from build.

commonMistakes.consequence: Tests fail because there are no compiled assemblies to test.
commonMistakes.correction: Run build before test, or omit --no-build from the test command.
